comment.author: 8077441@N08
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called London in the Georgian era, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 9122478@N03
comment._content: Portrait minatures first became popular in 16th century Europe, and by the 18th and 19th Century, painters became known for their specialism in the field.  They fulfilled the role of the modern day photograph, often given to family or loved ones while the sitter was away.

comment.author: 38123137@N00
comment._content: This portrait artist is probably the Irish born Nathaniel Hone [1718-1784]. He was active about York, etc., until about 1742 he married and moved to London. Some of his works are at the NPG -- www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person.php?LinkID=mp022... ~ Nice photo of image! We seek photos/ info re sitters/ artists of civic, etc. portraits. comment.author: 8525214@N06
comment._content: What a lovely miniature, the sitter looks like a Hanoverian to me! Many thanks for posting it to the 'worthies' group....

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content: You're welcome. I should say we do know a very little about this item. It was among the effects of Mary Smith, an inmate at Christ's Hospital in London. Because she was classed as insane, the Court of Chancery was responsible for the disposal of her estate but somehow her effects simply remained unclaimed alongside the court records. This miniature is one of five that she owned. You can see the range of items here: www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/museum/item.asp?item_id=32 I'll try and upload some more of them over the next few days.
